page.title: 13A VILLAGE SENIOR CITIZEN
page.content: MR. ALBERT THREADGOLD LEFT WEST BUTTERWICK VILLAGE SCHOOL DURING THE 1ST WORLD WAR AT THE AGE OF 12,ONE YEAR BEFORE THE NORMAL LEAVING AGE.APPLICATIONS COULD BE MADE FOR EARLY RELEASE BY FARMERS DURING THE WAR.CHILDREN WORE A KIND OF A UNIFORM; GIRLS-A WHITE SMOCK WITH A BLACK DRESS UNDERNEATH;BOYS:-JERSEYS AND KNICKERBOCKER TROUSERS.MR.THREADGOLD COULD REMEMBER CORN STACKS,AND THE FIRST COMBINE HARVESTER.THE STACKS WERE MADE OF CORN SHEAVES FASTENED DOWN WITH BANDS TIED TO STACK PEGS.THE STACKS WERE THATCHED TO KEEP OUT THE WEATHER.THE CORN WAS LEFT TO DRY.THEN A THRESHING MACHINE CAME FROM EPWORTH.FOUR MEN WORKED ON THE MACHINE;ONE FORKED THE SHEAVES FROM THE STACK;ONE CUT THE BANDS;ONE FED THE STRAW INTO A REVOLVING DRUM;THE OTHER FILLED THE SACKS WITH CORN.
